name: [1,4]benzodioxino[2,3-b]quinoxaline
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3603

name: [1,4]benzodioxino[2,3-b]quinoxaline
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3603
Reason: The compound [1,4]benzodioxino[2,3-b]quinoxaline is a complex structure consisting of a quinoxaline moiety fused with a benzodioxin ring system. The basic units to consider are quinoxaline and benzodioxin. Quinoxaline has a melting point of 30-31°C and typically, heteroaromatic compounds such as quinoxaline have higher melting points due to nitrogen atoms contributing to increased ring stability and hydrogen bonding. The presence of nitrogen likely adds about +100°C to the melting point. The benzodioxin moiety contains two oxygen atoms that contribute to hydrogen bonding, raising the melting point further; the effect of each oxygen can be estimated to add +40°C. Fusing rings typically increases the melting point due to increased rigidity of the structure. We can predict that the fusion of these two rings adds another +50°C. Therefore, the overall predicted increase in melting point due to the fusion and the presence of the nitrogen and oxygen atoms in the rings is approximately +230°C to the quinoxaline base structure's melting point.
Prediction: 260°C (30°C for quinoxaline base + 230°C for additional functional groups and ring fusion)
